While I agree with the statement by Jonathan about learning about these terrorist groups through monitoring them through open communications, these tools can also be used to send information that is meaningful only to the recipient. Think public key encryption. All can see the message, but only the recipient knows how to interpret. In this sense, all tools that can be used by terrorist organizations which are made by US companies should be regulated. For instance, there are many countries that are on the US export controlled list. These are countries where US companies are not allowed to export products/services that utilize certain encryption strengths.

Free speech and a free Internet is a key to global prosperity but US companies have a responsibility to limit support, even if it is PR/Communication enabling support to organizations that are known threats to US global interests and those of our allies. US export regulation today supports this goal and should continue to do so, even if it means shutting down the Twitter for groups like Hamas and Hezbollah.

I disagree in terms of the length of the flight between here and the UK in comparison to flying to the west coast. They are only roughly comparable. 5 1/2 hours is typical coast to coast. London is more like seven to eight hours away and, as an overnight flight in most cases, almost everyone wants to rest, per chance to sleep. Those biz and 1st class fares to the UK are, indeed, sky high, but they reflect the fact that a lot of people are on business. Some people even attempt a full day's work upon arrival in London.

There just isn't as much demand, from what I have seen, for biz and first class going to the coast. At two hours less travel time, it is just more manageable.

Another factor in terms of flying to London is that many passengers are likely heavy frequent fliers and thus buy their upgrades with miles. That leaves the rest of the seats open for whatever the airlines think they can get.

http://terryreport.com

London airports have some of the highest taxes of any city in the world, thus the high ticket price.

Gotta love big government!

The article revives a tangential question that has always remained in the back of my mind as unanswerable.

The trans-Atlantic route of NYC-London seems always at the top of all airlines' business model. The route is slightly longer than the transcontinental routes between NYC and Los Angeles or San Francisco. For going overseas, the route is too short to even get a decent nap before arrival. But the business class fares or first class fares for NYC-London route appear to be far more expensive than the ones for transcontinental routes. They may be the most expensive for any international routes. It was one of the two Concorde routes as well. But why?

For at least ten years, all business/first class fares to European destinations from any of the US hubs have gone on routine sales, several times a year. But I have not heard of fare sales for routes between Narita and US hubs. So I get the impression that trans-Atlantic routes do not bring in as much revenue as the big deal that the airlines accord them.

So, why does Delta salivate over this deal? An explanation that will enable me to add up the economic substance will be truly appreciated.

"Republicans claim to be for much smaller government, but as a political matter they have always attacked government spending in the abstract, never coming clean with voters about the reality that big cuts in government spending can happen only if we sharply curtail very popular programs."

Dr. Krugman, are you defining the military budget as a "very popular program"? I would not, and I believe that big cuts can be made in the budget without jeopardizing our defense. The military budget has been protected and even nurtured for quite some time, despite the recession, for political reasons, rather than for the overall benefit of the populace. There is tremendous waste and misallocation of resources now. While I don't believe that all of the budget woes can be solved through military cuts, I believe that it is an important piece of the puzzle, and that cuts to that budget can reduce pressures to cut other programs and perhaps some of the revenue pressure.

Austerity will lead to higher unemployment and a weaker economy. The government is the spender of last resort during an economic crisis. After WWII, the country made investments to grow the economy: interstate highway system, conversion of military plants, G.I. Bill, and the NASA program. By 1978, we reduced the debt from over 120 percent of GDP to under 30 percent.

It makes sense to reduce the $1 trillion budget for the military-industrial-security complex by a few hundred billion a year. The defense sector is not labor intensive. Infrastructure projects create 40 percent more jobs per dollar than spending on the military, health care creates 70 percent more jobs, and education creates 240 percent more jobs.

Jobs and growth, not austerity.

I think the trouble with concept of immortality (or reincarnation, more specifically, as it refers to this article) is that it is based on the paradigm that we will remember our past life in our new life. However it is possible that humans too have the ability to reincarnate or rejuvenate however in our new lives we cannot remember our past self. Without the consciousness of a former life, it is hard to determine if other species besides jellyfish are "immortal". In a way human life is like a jellyfish's; we begin as babies and as we grow up we slowly regress back into a state much like that of a baby's in our old age.
Also I think that the concept of mortality goes hand in hand with the concept of time. Similarly to the common perception of reincarnation, the popular belief is that time moves linearly. There is, however, a possibility that time moves in a circle, and that the lives we live have already been lived and will continue to be lived for eternity.
It is good that scientists study jellyfish "immortality" because although the general concept of immortality and reincarnation is a mystery that may never be solved, jellyfish immortality may help us to find ways to reverse or slow down the negative effects of aging.

This article is not about savants (which indeed comprise less than 1% of the autistic population), but about people whose intensive attention to detail--a hallmark of much of the autism spectrum--can be an asset to employers if taken advantage of in ways that are mutually beneficial to employer and employee.

And though some autistic people indeed are intellectually impaired as well, MOST are not. Autism is characterized by communication disability; this is superficially easy to mistake for intellectual disability, but it is not.

As my bank account lists it when it is deposited, I am, in the words of the US Treasury, an "annuitant." Social Security is then an annuity which I have purchased through the payroll tax, the amount I receive monthly calculated by actuaries based on my contributions over time and my life expectancy.

If we are worried about Social Security running out of funds then the present reduction of the payroll tax can't be helping any.

As it stands, they say that SS will not run out til mid-century by which time the baby boomers, myself included, will be dead and the problem of solvency of the system will be moot.
Well said, Oscar.  I won't repeat the points you made about the Social Security Trust Fund, but would add that Obama needs a push to advocate that  SS is not part of the deficit.

Speaking of bait and switch, here's what the GOP would like to do.

For the better part of three decades, the feds collected payroll taxes far in excess (until recently) of amounts needed to pay current beneficiaries. These taxes were collected mainly from the poor and middle class, as the income subject to this tax caps out at $110K. The percentage of income subject to payroll tax increased on the basis that the funds would be held in trust for future beneficiaries, but the Feds used this money to offset their deficit spending (racked up mainly by GOP administrations). And while the Feds claim they'll pay it back, the "entitlement reform" the GOP deems so necessary "to address our deficit problem" is really an attempt to deprive the poor and middle class of their dedicated contributions twice - once when the funds were withheld from their pay and a second time when benefits are cut.

Even factcheck.org has the misinformed view that these programs contribute to the deficit because the amounts raided from the trust fund must be repaid - which exacerbates the deficit. Well, so do our debts to other holders of treasuries, but we don't expect them to take a haircut because our debt to them contributes to the deficit. Moreover, this view ignores entirely the fact that these taxes were collected for a specific purpose.

Obama must make clear to the GOP that the debt to the trust fund is no different than any other debt, and therefore SS is not part of the deficit "problem".

Fred, the question of how long can the US run a deficit is Forever. The US can never default because their debt is owed in US$. They could eliminate the debt tomorrow by printing $100T in $100 bills and giving it to the people that owe them money. Now this would obviously cause massive inflation (the money would be effectively worthless) and would likely destroy the global economy, but it COULD be done.

The correct question therefore is not "how big can the deficit / debt get" but "at what level of defecit / debt does inflation become a major economic problem." As Dr. Krugman has pointed out in the past, higher inflation and a weakening of the US dollar would actually help job growth in the US, as imports would become more expensive and domestic suppliers would be more competitive.

There's a cause & effect relationship between [weaker dollar & more inflation] and [job growth & lower imports / less purchasing power]. The key is to find the right balance - too much inflation and the economy collapses; too little and nobody has a job. Right now inflation is very low and job growth is very low. An increase in inflation would lead to an increase in jobs.

So right now the Government should borrow more money and spend it to create jobs. Once the job market recovers (5-6% is about right), lower inflation, reduce government spending, and pay down the debt.

I was raised Catholic and spent years with sisters of St. Joseph and Ursuline orders. Nothing I ever experienced in those thousands of days equals the pride and gratitude I feel toward these women today , energetically active, being heard. I cannot thank them enough for standing against the endless, unchanging ignorance and arrogance of the "princes" of the Church. These nuns are giving us the sweetest breath of fresh air in the stale old oppression-as-usual halls of the Vatican since Pope John.

"My work is my prayer" is a comment from the nun noted above that will long be with me.

Blaming these excellent women serving selflessly as nurses, teachers, care givers to the old and much more, for the steep decline in the numbers of nuns? Really? And who is to blame for the sharp decline in the number of Catholic priests?

Beware: the ring-kissing rhetoric with which the Catholic Church denies the concerns of these dedicated women will no doubt drive their orders even faster toward the brink of extinction. Then who will spend their life's days teaching the young, feeding and clothing the poor, comforting the sick and the dying elderly? The princes?

I believe there are many today like me who are deeply proud of these nuns. Rise up, Catholic Sisters, and sing. And our deepest thanks for everything.
